Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us:  maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Today, the FOMC kept interest rates near zero and, in light of the progress the economy has made toward our goals, decided to begin reducing the pace of asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With these actions, monetary policy will continue to provide strong support to the economic recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Given the unprecedented nature of the disruptions related to the pandemic and the reopening of the economy, we remain attentive to risks and will ensure that our policy is well positioned to address the full range of plausible economic outcomes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I will say more about our monetary policy decisions after reviewing recent economic developments.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Economic activity expanded at a 6.5 percent pace in the first half of the year, reflecting progress on vaccinations, the reopening of the economy, and strong policy support.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In the third quarter, real GDP growth slowed notably from this rapid pace.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The summer’s surge in COVID cases from the Delta variant has held back the recovery in the sectors most adversely affected by the pandemic, including travel and leisure.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Activity has also been restrained by supply constraints and bottlenecks, notably in the motor vehicle industry.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As a result, both household spending and business investment flattened out last quarter.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nonetheless, aggregate demand has been very strong this year, buoyed by fiscal and monetary policy support and the healthy financial positions of households and businesses.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With COVID case counts receding further and progress on vaccinations, economic growth should pick up this quarter, resulting in strong growth for the year as a whole.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Conditions in the labor market have continued to improve, and demand for workers remains very strong.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement slowed with the rise in COVID cases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In August and September, job gains averaged 280,000 per month, down from an average of about 1 million jobs per month in June and July.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The slowdown has been concentrated in sectors most sensitive to the pandemic, including leisure and hospitality and education.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The unemployment rate was 4.8 percent in September.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This figure understates the shortfall in employment, particularly as participation in the labor market remains subdued.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Some of the softness in participation likely reflects the aging of the population and retirements.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But participation for prime-aged individuals also remains well below pre-pandemic levels—in part reflecting factors related to the pandemic, such as caregiving needs and ongoing concerns about the virus.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As a result, employers are having difficulties filling job openings.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: These impediments to labor supply should diminish with further progress on containing the virus—supporting gains in employment and economic activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Despite progress, joblessness continues to fall disproportionately on African Americans and Hispanics.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The supply and demand imbalances related to the pandemic and the reopening of the economy have contributed to sizable price increases in some sectors.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In particular, bottlenecks and supply chain disruptions are limiting how quickly production can respond to the rebound in demand in the near term.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As a result, overall inflation is running well above our 2 percent longer-run goal.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Supply constraints have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nonetheless, it remains the case that the drivers of higher inflation have been predominantly connected to the dislocations caused by the pandemic—specifically, the effects on supply and demand from the shutdown, the uneven reopening, and the ongoing effects of the virus itself.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We understand the difficulties that high inflation poses for individuals and families, particularly those with limited means to absorb higher prices for essentials such as food and transportation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our tools cannot ease supply constraints.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Like most forecasters, we continue to believe that our dynamic economy will adjust to the supply and demand imbalances and that, as it does, inflation will decline to levels much closer to our 2 percent longer-run goal.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, it is very difficult to predict the persistence of supply constraints or their effects on inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Global supply chains are complex; they will return to normal function, but the timing of that is highly uncertain.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are committed to our longer-run goal of 2 percent inflation and to having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at this goal.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If we were to see signs that the path of inflation, or [of] longer-term inflation expectations, was moving materially and persistently beyond levels consistent with our goal, we would use our tools to preserve price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will be watching carefully to see whether the economy is evolving in line with expectations.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Fed’s policy actions have been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our asset purchases have been a critical tool.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They helped preserve financial stability early in the pandemic and since then have helped foster smooth market functioning and accommodative financial conditions to support the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Last December, the Committee stated its intention to continue asset purchases at a pace of at least $120 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: At today’s meeting, the Committee judged that the economy has met this test, and decided to begin reducing the pace of its asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Beginning later this month, we will reduce the monthly pace of our net asset purchases by $10 billion for Treasury securities and $5 billion for agency mortgage-backed securities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We also announced another reduction of this size in the monthly purchase pace starting in mid-December, since that month’s purchase schedule will be released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York prior to our December FOMC meeting.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If the economy evolves broadly as expected, we judge that similar reductions in the pace of net asset purchases will likely be appropriate each month, implying that increases in our securities holdings would cease by the middle of next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That said, we are prepared to adjust the pace of purchases if warranted by changes in the economic outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And even after our balance sheet stops expanding, our holdings of securities will continue to support accommodative financial conditions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our decision today to begin tapering our asset purchases does not imply any direct signal regarding our interest rate policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We continue to articulate a different and more stringent test for the economic conditions that would need to be met before raising the federal funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We at the Fed will do everything we can to complete the recovery in employment and achieve our price-stability goal.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I look forward to your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: We’ll go to Nick at the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Chair Powell, the markets anticipate you will raise rates once or twice next year.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Are they wrong?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: So I would say it this way.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We try to focus on what we can control—and that is how to communicate as clearly as possible, in this highly uncertain world, how we’re thinking about the economic outlook and the balance of risks and how policy will evolve in that case and also in the cases, which are frequent, where the economy evolves in unexpected ways.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the focus at this meeting is on tapering asset purchases, not on raising rates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It is time to taper, we think, because the economy has achieved substantial further progress toward our goals, measured from last December.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t think it’s time yet to raise interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There is still ground to cover to reach maximum employment, both in terms of employment and in terms of participation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Getting to your question, our baseline expectation is that supply bottlenecks and shortages will persist well into next year, and elevated inflation as well, and that, as the pandemic subsides, supply chain bottlenecks will abate—and job growth will move back up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And as that happens, inflation will decline from today’s elevated levels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, the timing of that is highly uncertain.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, certainly, we should see inflation moving down by the second or third quarter.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The time for lifting rates and beginning to remove accommodation will depend on the path of the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think we can be patient.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If a response is called for, we will not hesitate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, what I will tell you is, we will be watching carefully to see whether the economy evolves in line with our expectations, and policy will adapt appropriately.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s what I would say.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Based on—if I could follow up, based on your current outlook for the labor market, do you think it’s possible—or likely, even—that maximum employment could be achieved by the second half of next year?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: So if you look at the progress that we’ve made over the course of the last year, if that pace were to continue, then the answer would be:  “Yes, I do think that that is possible.”  Of course, we measure maximum employment based on a wide range of figures, but it’s certainly within the realm of possibility.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Next, we’ll go to Jeanna at the New York Times.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: I was wondering if you could detail a little bit how you’re thinking about wages at this moment.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: Obviously, we’re seeing strong wage growth, particularly for people in sort of lower-income fields.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: I wonder if you see that as a positive thing or as a potential start to a wage–price spiral and sort of how you sort of delineate those two things.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: So wages have been moving up strongly, very strongly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, in particular, I would point to the employment compensation index reading that we got last Friday.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, in real terms, they’ve been—they had been running a little bit below inflation, so real wages were not really increasing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think, with the ECI reading, it becomes close to maybe not increasing, but close to back to zero in terms of the real increase.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So wages moving up, of course, is how standard of living increases over the years for generation upon generation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s very important, and it’s generally a good thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, the concern is a somewhat unusual case where, if wages were to be rising persistently and materially above inflation and productivity gains, that could put upward pressure on, or downward pressure on margins and cause companies to—or employers, really—to raise prices as a result, and you can see yourself, find yourself in what we used to call a wage–price spiral.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t have evidence of that yet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Productivity has been very high.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The ECI reading is just one reading.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Again, if you look back, we—so we’ll be watching this carefully.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I would say that, at this point, we don’t see troubling increases in wages.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we don’t expect those to emerge, but we’ll be watching carefully.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Next, we’ll go to Steve Liesman from CNBC.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: I wonder if you could perhaps give us your thinking about the tradeoffs between inflation and unemployment.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: You talked about the shortfall of unemployment—reemployment relative to before the pandemic, and yet you have inflation, which is affecting everybody.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Are we at, or close to, a point where the risk of inflation is greater than the benefit that you’d—for recovering these lost jobs so that now, from a risk-management standpoint, it makes sense to move more aggressively on rate hikes?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: And kind of a related question:  The statement today says you’ll keep policy accommodative until you hit that 2 percent inflation target.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Our surveys show looking for 5 percent inflation this year, 3½ percent next year—it sure seems like you’re on track to modestly or moderately exceed that 2 percent target.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I’m not sure I totally got your first question, but I would say—in fact, could you just quickly, succinctly, say your first question again?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Sure.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: The idea that the tradeoff between inflation and unemployment, that you would keep policy accommodative to put this 5 million folks, or find these 5 million jobs again, at the same time all Americans will be suffering from higher inflation—is that tradeoff worth it, or is it better or smarter to raise rates right now to combat inflation and perhaps not lean so heavily on the employment side of the mandate?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Yes, so, you know, this isn’t the traditional Phillips curve situation where there’s a direct tradeoff, where that’s really what we’re talking about.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The inflation that we’re seeing is really not due to a tight labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s due to bottlenecks, and it’s due to shortages, and it’s due to very strong demand meeting those.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think it’s not the classical situation where you have that precise tradeoff.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, in this situation, we do have a provision in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals, as you know, that says when those two things are in tension, what we do is, we take into account the employment shortfalls and inflation deviations and the potentially different time horizons over which employment and inflation are projected to return to levels judged consistent with the mandate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we used to call that the “balanced approach” paragraph.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have to think about the amount of the deviation, we have to think about the time it will take, and we have to make policy in a world where the two goals are in tension.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s very difficult.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But what it really boils down to is something that’s common sense.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that is risk management.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have to be aware of the risks that we’re—particularly now the risk of significantly higher inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We see shortages and bottlenecks persisting into next year, well into next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We see higher inflation persisting, and we have to be in position to address that risk should it become really a threat to—should it create a threat of more persistent, longer-term inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s what we think our policy is doing now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s putting us in a position to be able to address the range of plausible outcomes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: Next, we’ll go to Colby Smith at the Financial Times.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: Chair Powell, what are the economic conditions that would perhaps warrant a faster pace of tapering?
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: And I’m wondering how you would also characterize the risks that the Fed may actually need to accelerate that process eventually.
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: So I guess, as I said in my opening remarks, assuming the economy performs broadly as expected, the Committee judges that similar reductions in the pace of net asset purchases will likely be appropriate each month, and we’re prepared to deviate from that path if warranted by changes in the economic outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I’m not going to give you a lot more detail on what that might be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, if we do see something like that happening, if it becomes a question, then we’ll communicate very transparently and openly about that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I’m just going to leave it with the words that are in the statement.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Sorry, was there a second part?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: It’s just on characterizing the risks that you might actually have to do so later on.
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: You know, I would just leave you with the words we have here.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are prepared to speed up or slow down the pace of reductions in asset purchases if it’s warranted by changes in the economic outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, again, if we feel like something like that’s happening, then we’ll be very transparent about it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We wouldn’t want to surprise markets.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ll say, in light of this factor or these factors, we are considering doing this, and then we would either do it or not do it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But so—but I’m not going to, you know, start making up examples of what that might be today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: COLBY SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: Next one, Rachel Siegel at the Washington Post.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Thank you so much for taking our questions.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: You mentioned at the beginning that the Fed understands the difficulties that high inflation poses for individuals and families, especially those with limited means.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: What is your message to those families or consumers that are struggling with higher prices right now, and do you feel that your expectations around transitory inflation, that message is reaching them?
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, first of all, it is our job to—and we accept responsibility and accountability for inflation in the medium term.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re accountable to Congress and to the American people for maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The level of inflation we have right now is not at all consistent with price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: By the way, we’re also not at maximum employment, as I mentioned.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I would want to assure people that we will use our tools as appropriate to get inflation under control.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t think it’s a good time to raise interest rates, though, because we want to see the labor market heal further.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we have very good reason to think that that will happen as the Delta variant declines, so—which it’s doing now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So “transitory” is a word that people have had different understandings of.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For some, it carries a sense of “short lived,” and that’s, you know, there’s a real time component—measured in months, let’s say.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Really, for us, what “transitory” has meant is that if something is transitory, it will not leave behind it permanently or very persistently higher inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s why we, you know, we took a step back from “transitory.”   We said “expected to be transitory,” first of all, to show uncertainty around that—we’ve always said that, by the way, in other contexts; we just hadn’t done it in the statement—but also to acknowledge, really, that it means different things to different people.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And then we added some language to really explain more what we’re talking about in paragraph two and paragraph three.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We said that “supply and demand imbalances related to the pandemic and the reopening of the economy have contributed to sizable price increases,” and we said, “Progress on vaccinations and an easing of supply constraints are expected to support continued gains in economic activity and employment as well as a reduction in inflation.”  So we’re trying to explain what we mean and also acknowledging more uncertainty about “transitory.”   So it’s, I mean, it’s become a word that’s attracted a lot of attention that maybe is distracting from our message, which we want to be as clear as possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Ultimately, the only other thing I would say is, look, we understand completely that it’s particularly people who are living paycheck to paycheck or seeing higher grocery costs, higher gasoline costs—when the winter comes, higher heating costs for their homes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We understand completely what they’re going through.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, we will use our tools over time to make sure that that doesn’t become a permanent feature of life.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Really, that’s one of our principal jobs, along with achieving maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s our commitment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: We’ll go to Chris Rugaber of the Associated Press.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Great.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Thank you, Michelle.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Thank you, Chair Powell.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Well, I wonder if you could update us.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: You talked about getting back to full employment, and so could you update how you define that?
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: I mean, you’ve, you know—a few months ago, yourself and other Fed officials talked about getting back to the pre-COVID labor market.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: There were even hints you might try to do something better than that.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Now we heard talk of, as you mentioned, people retiring, and there’s talk of not being able to get back as—all the jobs back because of that and other trends.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: You did mention the prime-age folks.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: So can you give us some examples of things you're looking at, specifically, to measure full employment?
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Will you be looking at prime-age employment population ratio, for example, and, if so, do you need to see it get back to pre-COVID levels to achieve maximum employment, or is there something short of that that would work?
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHRIS RUGABER.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So maximum employment is, it’s a broad—what would we say?—broad-based and inclusive goal that’s not directly measurable and changes over time due to various factors.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You can’t specify a specific goal.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s taking into account quite a broad range of things, and, of course, employment—levels of employment—[and] participation are a part of that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, in addition, there are other measures of what’s going on in the labor market, like wages is a key measure of how tight the labor market is—the level of quits, the amount of job openings, the flows in and out of various states.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we look at so many different things, and you make an overall judgment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, the temptation at the beginning of the recovery was to look at the data in February of 2020 and say, well, that’s the goal because we didn’t know any—that’s what we knew.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We knew that was achievable in a context of low inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think we’re in a, you know, we’re learning that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have to be humble about what we know about this economy, which is still very, you know, COVID-affected, by the way.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: A lot of what we’re seeing in the last 90 days is because of Delta.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We were on a path to a very different place.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Delta put us on a different path.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we see these things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, so I think we’re going to have to—ideally, we would have, we would see further development of the labor market in a context where there isn’t another COVID spike, and then we would be able to see, I think, a lot.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We would see whether—how does participation react in that world, in that sort of post-COVID world?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Right now, people are staying out of the labor market because of caretaking [and] because of fear of COVID to a significant extent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we thought that schools reopening and elapsing unemployment benefits would produce some sort of additional labor supply.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That doesn’t seem to have been the case, interestingly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think there’s room for a whole lot of humility here, as we try to think about what maximum employment would be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to have to see some time post-COVID so that we know—or post-Delta, anyway—to see what is possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think the learning for those of us who lived through the last cycle is that, over time, you can get to places that didn’t look possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, what we also have now, though, is, we have high inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we have a completely different situation now where we have high inflation, and we have to balance that with what’s going on in the employment market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s a complicated situation, and I would say, we will, we hope to achieve significantly greater clarity about where this economy is going and what the characteristics of the post-pandemic economy are over the first half of next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: We’ll go to Howard Schneider at Reuters.
Speaker: JOE PAVEL.

Sentences: Thanks, and thanks for doing this.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: So, given that answer about employment, I would like to get back to Steve’s question a little bit.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: On a headline basis, just as it’s evolved this year, do you feel that the two tests on inflation have been met?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Sorry, the two tests?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The two tests in the statement—the guidance that it has to hit 2 percent and be on track to moderately be above 2 percent.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Has the economy cleared that?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: That’s a decision for the Committee.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would put it to you this way.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: When we reach maximum employment, when we reach a state where labor market conditions are at maximum employment in the Committee’s judgment, it’s very possible that the inflation test will already be met.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re aware that that language sounds, it sounds a little out of touch with what’s going on, but, you know, we’re not at maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: When that is the case, we’ll look to see whether the inflation test is met, and there’s a good chance that it will be if you look at how inflation has evolved in the last year and a half.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, to follow up, so you’re not willing to commit that the current levels of inflation and their persistence have met “moderately” and “for some time.”  So, given that, I mean, how should we wonder what “moderately” over and “for some time” mean?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: What I’m really saying is, that question is not before us right now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we had the question on when to taper.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve now answered that question and the speed of it and all that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have not focused on whether we meet the liftoff test, because we don’t meet the liftoff test now because we’re not at maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: What I’m saying is, given where inflation is and where it’s projected to be, let’s say we do meet the maximum-employment test.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Then the Committee—the question for the Committee at that time will be, has the inflation test been met?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, I don’t want to get ahead of the Committee on that, but the answer may very well be “Yes, it’s been met.”  But we’re not asking that question today, because we’re not running a liftoff test.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re not evaluating the liftoff test today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We didn’t have that discussion at today’s meeting.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We did talk about the economy and the development of the economy, but we didn’t ask ourselves whether the liftoff test is met, because, you know, it’s clearly not met on the maximum-employment side.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Let’s go to Matthew Boesler at Bloomberg.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: Matthew Boesler with Bloomberg.
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: So, when you’re looking at this question of assessing whether or not the U.S. economy is at maximum employment, do you have a framework for making that judgment that is independent of what inflation is doing?
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: And, if not, does it kind of complicate that assessment, given all of the uncertainty about inflation right now and the inclination to believe that, you know, the high inflation we’re seeing is not related to capacity utilization in the labor market?
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: So we don’t actually define maximum employment as—we define it in terms of inflation, but, of course, there is a connection there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Maximum employment has to be a level that is consistent with stable prices.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But that’s not really how we think about it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think about maximum employment as looking at a broad range of things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You can’t just look at—unlike inflation, where you can have a number.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But with maximum employment, you could be in a situation, hypothetically, where the unemployment rate is low, but there are many people who are out of the labor force and will come back in.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so you wouldn’t really be at maximum employment, because there’s this group that isn’t counted as unemployed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we look at a range of things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the thing is, by many measures, we are at a very tight labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mentioned quits and job openings and wages and things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many of them are signaling a tight labor market, but the issue is, how persistent is that?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Because you have people who are held out of the labor market, you know, of their own—they’re holding themselves out of the labor market because of caretaking needs or because of fear of COVID, or, for whatever reason, they’re staying out.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And it’s clear that there are, you know—with tremendous demand for workers and wages moving up, it does seem like we’re set up to go back to a higher job-creation rate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that would suggest that you’re not at maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, at the end of the day, it is a judgment thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, of course, at the end of it, it also has to be a level of employment that’s consistent with price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And if I could just follow up briefly, you know, you’ve talked a little bit about this possibility that the two goals might be in tension and how you would have to balance those two things.
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: Could you talk a little bit about what the Fed’s process for balancing those two goals would be in the event that, say, come next year, you decide there’s a serious risk of persistent inflationary pressures despite ongoing employment shortfalls?
Speaker: MATTHEW BOESLER.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mean, again, it’s a risk-management thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s not—I can’t reduce it to an equation, but, ultimately, it’s about risk management.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So you want to be in a position to act, to cover the full range of plausible outcomes, not just the base case.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And in this case, the risk is skewed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For now, it appears to be skewed toward higher inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we need to be in a position to act in case it becomes necessary to do so or appropriate to do so, and we think we will be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s how we’re thinking about it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think, though, that, judgmentally, too, it’s appropriate to be patient.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s appropriate for us to see what the labor market and what the economy look like when they heal further.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We know that we were on a path to a different place, as I mentioned, when Delta arrived.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And Delta stopped, it stopped job creation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It stopped that transition away from a goods-focused economy where there’s excess demand for goods because there—services are not available.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: People are not traveling.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That transition itself could help bring inflation down, because, presumably, people would spend a little less on goods while they start spending more on travel and all sorts of travel services and things like that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we want to see that healthy process unfold as we decide what the true state of the economy is, and we think it will evolve in a way that will mean lower inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Bottlenecks should be abating.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We start to see that now with some of them, but, overall, they haven’t gotten better overall, and, you know, we’re very aware of that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s really how we’re thinking about it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re thinking that time will tell us more.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In the meantime, we don’t think it’s time to raise rates now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, if we do conclude that it’s necessary to do so, then we’ll be patient, but we won’t hesitate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Let’s go to Edward Lawrence at Fox Business.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman, for taking the call.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: So the Federal Reserve—I want to talk about climate change.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: The Federal Reserve released a statement today—says “the Federal Reserve supports the efforts .
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: . . to identify key issues and potential solutions for the climate-related challenges most relevant to central banks and supervisory” outcomes.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: Is this putting us on the path to regulate what banks can offer loans on or invest in, like coal plants or fossil fuels?
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: So that’s not a decision for bank regulators or for any agency.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s a decision for elected representatives.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we feel that any role that we have—and we do think we have a role in climate change.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It relates to our existing mandates, and our existing mandates are, really, prudential regulation of financial institutions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We expect them, and the public will expect us to expect them, to understand and be in a position to manage their risks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s physical risk, and it’s transition risk for climate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, by the way, the large financial institutions are doing this already, and, you know, we think that’s right within our mandate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There’s also a financial stability question, the overall stability of the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so, from that standpoint, we can do research.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can try to help understand what will the pathways be through which climate change effects the economy—both physical risk and transition risk.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s what we can do, and that’s what we will do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’ll do it well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Within the frame of our existing mandates, we’ll do it well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re not the people who will decide the national strategy on climate change.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That has to be elected people, and not so much us.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We feel like we have that narrow mandate, and we will do it well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: Great, thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Victoria Guida at Politico.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: So the Fed recently announced that there is going to be new conflict-of-interest rules for investments by Fed officials, and this follows, obviously, the resignation of two regional Fed presidents.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: And I’m just wondering, do you think that there is more that you will need to do to rebuild the credibility of the Fed, such as, you know, requiring officials to put their assets in blind trusts?
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: And also, if you could speak to whether you have any concerns that any rules or laws were broken by Fed officials.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: So we, you know, we—let me just say that this system, the ethics system we had in place had been in place for decades and had, as far as we know, served us well, and then that was no longer the case.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so we had no moment of denial about that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As a group, we stepped in, and we took the actions that we took.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, within one FOMC cycle, we announced a new set of rules to, you know, to try to put us back where we need to be, which is, we need to have the complete trust of the American people that we’re working in their interest all the time—absolutely critical to our work, as it is for any government agency.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I feel like this called that into question.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we reacted, I would characterize it, strongly and forcefully.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If there were other things that we could do that were reasonable, we would certainly do them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So you asked me about blind trusts.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, the overall authority for ethics around these issues in the federal government is the Office of Government Ethics, OGE.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And they have a long-held position which is not favorable to blind trusts.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They do not encourage them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They don’t think they’re effective.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They think they’re cumbersome.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And they think there are better ways to get at the things that need to be done.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And those are the things that we’re actually doing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I don’t know that there are any blind trusts, for that reason, because they are the, they’re the regulator.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They say this on their website, if you look.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of laws broken, you know, I asked the inspector general to look to see whether there were rules broken and whether there were laws broken, and I won’t speculate on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But that is with the inspector general now and, of course, out of my hands.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: We’ll go to Mike McKee at Bloomberg.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, the critics of your patience policy argue that, given the long and variable lags with which monetary policy works, that you are likely to end up, given inflation, by having to raise rates faster and farther than you would have liked and, therefore, send the economy into recession.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: Given the fact that, basically, your forecast has been chasing inflation over the last year, and now you’re talking about it not coming down until the second or third quarter, why would they be wrong in thinking that?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: Well, so, let me say what’s happened—and we’re very, very straightforward about it—is that inflation has come in higher than expected, and bottlenecks have been more persistent and more prevalent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We see that just like everybody else does, and we see that they’re now on track to persist well into next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That was not expected—not expected by us, not expected by other macro forecasters.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, let me say, you know, it’s difficult enough to just forecast the economy in normal times.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: When you’re talking about, you know, global supply chains in turmoil, it’s a whole different thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And you’re talking about a pandemic that’s holding people out of the labor force for reasons that we can sample, but we don’t have a lot of experience with this.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s very, very difficult to forecast and not easy to set policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we have to set policy, though.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s what we’re doing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, so, to look at your question this way, I don’t think that we’re behind the curve.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I actually believe that policy is well positioned to address the range of plausible outcomes, and that’s what we need to do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I do think it would be premature to raise rates today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s not—I don’t think that’s controversial.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Certainly, I don’t know anyone arguing for that today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the reason is that there’s still ground to cover to get to maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we don’t want to stop that when there’s good reason to think—there’s still good reason to think, although it’s been delayed, clearly, there’s good reason to think that the economy will reopen, particularly if we do get past, you know, significant outbreaks of COVID.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s when we’re really going to see what the characteristics of the labor market are.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, I think, you know, the bottlenecks that we’re seeing in global supply chains around goods and, frankly, now at our own domestic ports, because demand is stronger than the capacity of those ports—those things are going to work themselves out.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have a flexible economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’ll take some time, but, you know, it took—you know, the experts managed to create a vaccine faster than, certainly, than I expected.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think this stuff will work itself out over the course of next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That is my baseline understanding, and that’s a very widely held one among people.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, we are prepared for different eventualities, and we will use our tools to achieve price stability and maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re going to let the data lead us to where we need to go.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our policy will adapt—and has already adapted—to the changing understanding of inflation and of bottlenecks and the whole supply-side story—which is also partly a demand story.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So our policy will continue to adapt as is appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Let’s go to Nancy Marshall-Genzer at Marketplace.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentences: Thanks for taking our questions.
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentences: So you announced that the Fed is going to taper at a rate of, starting at $15 billion a month, and that’s more than twice the pace of the last taper.
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentences: So why are you tapering faster this time?
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentences: The economy is in quite a different place than when we tapered back in, I guess it was, 2013.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We were much farther away from maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Inflation was much lower.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This is an economy where demand is very, very strong, very strong, and job openings substantially exceed the number of unemployed people.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the need for further stimulus is far less than it was in 2013, where we still had quite a ways to go.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mean, after we began that taper, it was still many years before we reached what I would characterize as conditions consistent with maximum employment, let alone price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So this is quite a different situation, and, you know, the Committee unanimously felt today that we had met the test that we’d articulated, and this was appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And this is faster than, you know, than what people had expected six months ago.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s earlier and faster, and that’s because our, as I mentioned, our policy has been adapting to the situation as it evolves, as it’s clarifying itself, and that’s partly because we see inflation coming in higher—so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Let’s go to Mike Derby.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Yes, thank you for taking my question.
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: I wonder if the Fed has given any thoughts yet to the endgame for the balance sheet in terms of, you know, once you get the taper process complete, will you hold the balance sheet steady, or will you allow it to start passively winding down?
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: And then, in a related question, do you have any greater insight into what Fed bond buying actually does for the economy?
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: In terms of its economic impact, have you been able to, you know, measure it or quantify it in any fashion, you know, because I’m sure you know there’s often been questions about, what is bond buying actually doing to help the economy?
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: Sure.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So in terms of the balance sheet, those questions that you mention—we haven’t gone back to them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now that we’ve tapered, I expect that that’s exactly what we’ll do in coming meetings.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’ll do it in an orderly fashion, and we’ll talk about reinvestment and all those things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we don’t have to make decisions on those yet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, typically, when we’re doing a new subject like that, we’ll have a series of briefings and discussions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s what we will now begin to do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of the effect of asset purchases on the economy, so, there’s a tremendous amount of research and scholarship on this.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, you can kind of—you can find different people coming out with different views.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I would say, the most mainstream view would be that you’re at the effective lower bound, so how do you affect longer-term rates?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are two ways.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: One, so you can’t lower rates—let’s say you can’t lower rates any further, hypothetically.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So you can give forward guidance.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You can say, we’re going to keep the rates low for a period of time, either [for] a specific period, [or] until certain conditions are met.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The markets will do the math, and that’ll have an effect on longer-term borrowings even, you know, 10, 30 years out kind of thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s one thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The other thing you can do is, you just go buy those securities, buy longer-term securities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That will drive down longer-term rates and hold them lower, and, you know, rates right across the, right across the rate spectrum matter for borrowers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So lower rates encourage more borrowing, encourage more economic activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: People—you can service your debt.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You have more free cash flow.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, it’s not different from what we do at the short end.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that was discussed long before anybody did it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That was—I think Milton Friedman said that that was what you could do if you were pinned at the lower bound, many, many years ago.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, anyway, that’s how it’s supposed to work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, it’s quite hard to be precise about these things because, you know, you only have one economy, and you can’t run two different economies right next to each other and do a scientific experiment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But most people find—most of the findings are that it does support economic activity in the way that you would expect, which is to say, at the margin, more economic activity with lower rates, which is why we do what we do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: More accommodative financial conditions lead to more economic activity, over time, with a lag.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think that’s the main finding I would say on QE.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: We’re going to go to Paul Lamonica at CNN.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Chair Powell, Chair Powell, you’ve addressed already questions about the stock purchases that took place from some of the regional Fed presidents and, you know, addressing the American people to make sure that they can trust the Fed.
Speaker: PAUL LAMONICA.

Sentences: I was wondering, also, in light of the fact that, you know, we now have questions about your own future, whether or not President Biden will nominate you for a second term, what would you say—to the President and to senators that, potentially, you know, will be voting on a renomination—about this, specifically with regards to your future as Fed Chair for a possible second term?
Speaker: PAUL LAMONICA.

Sentences: So I’m not going to—I won’t have any—I will answer your question, Paul, but I’m not going to have any comment whatsoever on the renomination process at all.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Fair enough.
Speaker: PAUL LAMONICA.

Sentences: I will say, though, that I have briefed Administration officials, and I’ve briefed people on Capitol Hill in detail about what we did and why we did it, and seeking their feedback, getting their reaction.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, this is—part of my job is—Congress has oversight over the Fed, and we take that very seriously.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So if you’re on our, one of the two committees that has oversight over us, then I’m in regular contact with you, probably.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, when something like this comes up, I’m on the phone.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I’m offering to meet with you and explain it to you and answer your questions and identify any concerns people might have.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s just part of my job.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I don’t talk about particular conversations.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But you can assume I’ll always do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I certainly did it in this case.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: PAUL LAMONICA.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Let’s go to Hannah Lang at the American Banker.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: I wanted to ask about the supplementary leverage ratio.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: Is the Fed still planning on taking comment on ways to permanently address that, and how concerned are you, ultimately, about banks’ willingness to intermediate in the Treasury markets without a permanent fix?
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: So I don’t have anything for you on supplemental leverage ratio right now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are looking at ways to, if there are ways we can address liquidity issues through that channel.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re also—we also have a—there’s a working group headed by [the] Treasury about, over Treasury [securities] markets, and what happened in the acute phase of the pandemic, and what structural things may need to be done.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that would be part of that workstream, and I know that there’s a lot going on.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I’m not sure when that report will be out.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s work under way.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s one of the many issues that are part of that, along with things like central clearing of Treasuries, greater central clearing, and, you know, many other ideas.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s important that we have a liquid Treasury [securities] market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s a huge public benefit that we do, and, you know, I think we need to do those things that enable that, you know, while also assuring the safety and soundness of our largest financial institutions, who tend to be the main dealers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we have to make sure that that’s always a first order of concern as well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Let’s go to Brian Cheung at Yahoo Finance.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chairman Powell.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: Brian Cheung, Yahoo Finance.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: So, just to expand on the ethics conversation, you talked about how you engage with people on Capitol Hill and in the Administration.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: You talked about what you’ve done already, but I’m just wondering if you can take a step back and just assess whether or not there was reputational damage as a result of that, either from the public’s view or from the financial community’s view of the Federal Reserve’s independence.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And then, secondly, do you look back on the whole episode and have thoughts on your individual responsibility in preventing something like this from having happened?
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: CHAIR POWELL  You know, I think it’s too soon to say what the reputational damage is.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: I think, from the very beginning, my reaction was:  We need to deal with this straightforwardly, transparently, and forcefully.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And that’s what we’re going to do.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: I mean, it’s, it means everything to me that we do whatever it takes to make sure that nothing like this happens again, and I like to think we’ve made a real good start on that.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: If you think about it, you cannot execute a trade unless it’s precleared, and then you have to say, “Execute.”  It’s not even a trade.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: Really, there’s no trading going on.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: This is for investment and, you know, getting liquidity for life’s expenses.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: But you then have to wait 45 days to actually execute that sale or purchase.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: So I think it’s a pretty good system.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: We’ll always be looking to make it better.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: So in terms of our independence, you know, look, I think we will address this, and I think we have.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And I like to think it’s enough, but it’s going to, you know—we’re just beginning to implement it.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: We have to write the rules, which we’re doing, you know, as quickly as possible.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: We need more people.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: We’re going to have to resource this much more significantly here at the Board, and also, we’re going to need appropriate technology, because, you know, the Fed has more than—the System has more than 30,000 employees.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: Not all of them, far few of them, will be covered by this, but the senior officers, who will be covered by this, will, you know, will have to have technology access, and it’s going to have to work efficiently.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: So there’s a lot of work to do to implement.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: You know, again, I would just say, this system has been in place for decades.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And it was in place when I took over.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: It was in place for the last, at least the last three or four Chairs.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And, you know, it was what it was.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And, you know, it proved to have weaknesses in it.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And part of that was, it wasn’t uniformly enforced across the System.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: I’m a big believer in the value of the Federal Reserve System and the Reserve Banks.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: But you had 12 different ethics officers at 12 different Banks.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And you had ethics people here.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And, you know, compliance wasn’t, it wasn’t all exactly the same.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: It was a little bit different and uneven, and also, the rules were—you know, we didn’t imagine the problems that happened.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And they may have actually been—I don’t know this—but they may actually have been in compliance with the specifics of our rules.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: They were clearly not in compliance with the part of our rules that said, don’t do anything that would create that appearance.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: I mean, that’s clear.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: This was a bad appearance.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: So, anyway, what can we do?
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: We are where we are.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: It happened, and we just have to deal with it forthrightly and transparently and “own” it and step up to this, you know, meet this moment.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: I’m totally committed to doing that.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: And, again, if there are better ideas, I’d love to hear them, but I think we have so far made a good start.
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: When you say you spoke with Administration officials, did that include the President?
Speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG.

Sentences: I’m not going to answer who I spoke to at all.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I just, I’m not going to give you any names, so don’t take that as a “yes” or “no.”  I’m just not going to start down that road.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Okay.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: We’re going to go to Jeff Cox for the last question.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Yes, thank you.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: Chair, I just want to dig a little bit deeper on employment.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: We’ve seen what’s been called the great resignation, folks leaving their jobs in record numbers.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: Is there any feeling there that maybe you’ve been accused of “fighting the last war”—that perhaps the labor dynamics have changed in the post-COVID environment and that full employment may not look like what it looked like before?
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, what’s happening is, people are leaving their jobs.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They’re quitting their jobs in all-time-high numbers—but, in many cases, going back into employment and getting higher wages.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So a lot of the higher wages you’re seeing are for job switchers rather than incumbents.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s just, that’s a sign of a really strong labor market, as opposed to people just running off and quitting.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There have also been—there are a significant number of retirements, and we’ll just have to see what that means.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, toward the end of the last cycle, which was the longest in our recorded economic history, we did see labor force participation moving up well above what economists estimate was the trend, and part of that was people staying in the labor force or just not retiring at the rates they were expected to retire.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So maybe this was just catch-up on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I am a believer that, over time, you won’t know how far—you won’t know what can happen with labor force participation in advance.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You’re just going to have to give it some time, because we saw that over and over again.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are things that we can, where we can say, you know, this is where the limit is.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Labor force participation is a much more flexible subject for me, and so I do think we need to be humble about what the limits are of labor force participation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But we expect labor force participation to pick up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t know the pace at which it will do so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So in terms of full employment, as I discussed earlier, I think, at the very beginning of the recovery, the natural thing to do was to look back at labor conditions, labor market conditions in February of 2010, at the end of the longest expansion in our history.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There was so much to like about that labor market, a really historically good labor market—never perfect, but a good labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re in a different world now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This is a—it’s just very different.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The pandemic recession was the deepest, and the recovery has been the fastest.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And wages didn’t really go down.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, real incomes were more than fully replaced by fiscal policy [support].
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: All of this is completely unusual.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, an economy where inflation was driven by services is now inflation where—all the inflation is in goods, which have had negative inflation for a quarter-century.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So you ask about full employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think we have to—I’m very open to the thought that it’s going to be an empirical question of where it is located, and we’re just going to learn more and more.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mean, one thing we’ll learn, I think, I hope we’ll learn in the next, in the near term is, once the Delta variant really does continue to decline, what’s going to happen to employment?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Are we going to start to see over the winter, you know, significant increases in jobs again?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If you look back, the three-, six-, and nine-month average job creation is between 550,000 and 600,000.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So if you think of that as a stronger—you don’t have to think back to the million-job months of June and July.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You can just think, okay, 550 to 600—if we should get back on that path, then we would be making good progress, and we like to see that, of course.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’ll know so much more.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, believe me, we understand.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s a different world in so many ways.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re very open to that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Chair, and thank you all for joining us today.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.
